result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Signed by Judge Carter on 08/30/2022.
Effective August 1, 2022, this case is assigned to Branch 4, the Honorable Lloyd V. Carter, pursuant to 22-SO-04(67).

Jury status hearing on November 17, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Jury trial - 12 person on November 29, 2022 at 08:30 am.

09:27 AM Defendant Bruce M Hencsik in court with attorney Anna M Kees and SPD intern Sicula .   District Attorney's Office Law Intern Nikole Kane appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Victim rights have been complied with by the Waukesha County District Attorneys Office. Victim appeared in person in court. 

Defense is requesting matter be scheduled for trial. 
Victim presented a statement to the Court. 

State is unsure if additional referrals have been made. 

Court sets jury trial date. 

Court takes no action on bond at this time, however if any referrals or contacts with law enforcement are provided to the Court. Court will address modifying bond.  Jury trial - 12 person scheduled for November 29, 2022 at 08:30 am.  Jury status hearing scheduled for November 17, 2022 at 09:00 am.
